comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Walter Damrosch (1862-1950), German-born American composer and conductor: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Damrosch

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
June 3, 1914: Commencement exercises at Columbia University, New York City.

A Bain'LOC photo of Walter Damrosch on the deck of a boat in New York harbor:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5083444595/]

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Damrosch received an honorary Doctor of Music. See next day's NYT of June 4, 1914 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0614F63C5E13738...

comment.author: 70304095@N02
comment._content: Could it be that the third man, on the right outer side, is Richard Gottheil (1862-1936)? Please see the portrait that accompanies his entry in the Encyclopaedia Iranica?

comment.author: 70304095@N02
comment._content:
Another view of the same man can be had in this photo from the same series:
hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ggbain.16165

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Islamic books: thank you for your information. It possibly could be Gottheil who taught Semitic languages and rabbinical literature at Columbia during this time period as described in the Encyclopaedia Iranica article: www.iranicaonline.org/articles/gottheil-richard-james-hor... We can can "possibly" to our description until more confirming information turns up.

comment.author: 70304095@N02
comment._content: Thanks to Google Image Search, here is a poorly reproduced photo of Gottheil, as a much younger man but also showing his profile, in The Menorah Journal, 1/3 (1915): www.gutenberg.org/files/22300/22300-h/meno-3.html
